speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: SCENE II. The forest.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO, with a paper

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And thou, thrice-crowned queen of night, survey

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: With thy chaste eye, from thy pale sphere above,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Thy huntress' name that my full life doth sway.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: O Rosalind! these trees shall be my books

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And in their barks my thoughts I'll character;

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: That every eye which in this forest looks

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Shall see thy virtue witness'd every where.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Run, run, Orlando; carve on every tree

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: The fair, the chaste and unexpressive she.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter CORIN and TOUCHSTONE

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And how like you this shepherd's life, Master Touchstone?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: life, but in respect that it is a shepherd's life,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: it is naught. In respect that it is solitary, I

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: like it very well; but in respect that it is

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: private, it is a very vile life. Now, in respect it

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; but in

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: respect it is not in the court, it is tedious. As

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: is it a spare life, look you, it fits my humour well;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: but as there is no more plenty in it, it goes much

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: against my stomach. Hast any philosophy in thee, shepherd?

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: No more but that I know the more one sickens the

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: worse at ease he is; and that he that wants money,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: means and content is without three good friends;

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: that the property of rain is to wet and fire to

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: burn; that good pasture makes fat sheep, and that a

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: great cause of the night is lack of the sun; that

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: he that hath learned no wit by nature nor art may

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: complain of good breeding or comes of a very dull kindred.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Such a one is a natural philosopher. Wast ever in

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: court, shepherd?

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: No, truly.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Then thou art damned.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Nay, I hope.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, thou art damned like an ill-roasted egg, all

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: on one side.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: For not being at court? Your reason.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Why, if thou never wast at court, thou never sawest

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: good manners; if thou never sawest good manners,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: then thy manners must be wicked; and wickedness is

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: sin, and sin is damnation. Thou art in a parlous

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: state, shepherd.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Not a whit, Touchstone: those that are good manners

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: behavior of the country is most mockable at the

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: court. You told me you salute not at the court, but

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: you kiss your hands: that courtesy would be

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: uncleanly, if courtiers were shepherds.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Instance, briefly; come, instance.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Why, we are still handling our ewes, and their

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: fells, you know, are greasy.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Why, do not your courtier's hands sweat? and is not

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: a man? Shallow, shallow. A better instance, I say; come.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Besides, our hands are hard.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Your lips will feel them the sooner. Shallow again.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: A more sounder instance, come.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And they are often tarred over with the surgery of

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: our sheep: and would you have us kiss tar? The

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: courtier's hands are perfumed with civet.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Most shallow man! thou worms-meat, in respect of a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: good piece of flesh indeed! Learn of the wise, and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: perpend: civet is of a baser birth than tar, the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: very uncleanly flux of a cat. Mend the instance, shepherd.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: You have too courtly a wit for me: I'll rest.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Wilt thou rest damned? God help thee, shallow man!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: God make incision in thee! thou art raw.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Sir, I am a true labourer: I earn that I eat, get

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: that I wear, owe no man hate, envy no man's

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: happiness, glad of other men's good, content with my

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: harm, and the greatest of my pride is to see my ewes

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: graze and my lambs suck.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: That is another simple sin in you, to bring the ewes

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: and the rams together and to offer to get your

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: living by the copulation of cattle; to be bawd to a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: bell-wether, and to betray a she-lamb of a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: twelvemonth to a crooked-pated, old, cuckoldly ram,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: out of all reasonable match. If thou beest not

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: damned for this, the devil himself will have no

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: shepherds; I cannot see else how thou shouldst

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: 'scape.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistress's brother.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND, with a paper, reading

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: From the east to western Ind,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No jewel is like Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Her worth, being mounted on the wind,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Through all the world bears Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: All the pictures fairest lined

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Are but black to Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Let no fair be kept in mind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But the fair of Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I'll rhyme you so eight years together, dinners and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: suppers and sleeping-hours excepted: it is the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: right butter-women's rank to market.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Out, fool!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: For a taste:

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: If a hart do lack a hind,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Let him seek out Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: If the cat will after kind,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: So be sure will Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Winter garments must be lined,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: So must slender Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: They that reap must sheaf and bind;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Then to cart with Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Sweetest nut hath sourest rind,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Such a nut is Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: He that sweetest rose will find

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Must find love's prick and Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: This is the very false gallop of verses: why do you

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: infect yourself with them?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Peace, you dull fool! I found them on a tree.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, the tree yields bad fruit.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I'll graff it with you, and then I shall graff it

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: with a medlar: then it will be the earliest fruit

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: i' the country; for you'll be rotten ere you be half

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: ripe, and that's the right virtue of the medlar.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: You have said; but whether wisely or no, let the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: forest judge.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Enter CELIA, with a writing

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Peace! Here comes my sister, reading: stand aside.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: [Reads]

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Why should this a desert be?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: For it is unpeopled? No:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Tongues I'll hang on every tree,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: That shall civil sayings show:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Some, how brief the life of man

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Runs his erring pilgrimage,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: That the stretching of a span

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Buckles in his sum of age;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Some, of violated vows

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: 'Twixt the souls of friend and friend:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: But upon the fairest boughs,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Or at every sentence end,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Will I Rosalinda write,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Teaching all that read to know

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: The quintessence of every sprite

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Heaven would in little show.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Therefore Heaven Nature charged

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: That one body should be fill'd

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: With all graces wide-enlarged:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Nature presently distill'd

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Helen's cheek, but not her heart,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Cleopatra's majesty,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Atalanta's better part,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Sad Lucretia's modesty.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Thus Rosalind of many parts

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: By heavenly synod was devised,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Of many faces, eyes and hearts,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: To have the touches dearest prized.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Heaven would that she these gifts should have,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And I to live and die her slave.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O most gentle pulpiter! what tedious homily of love

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: have you wearied your parishioners withal, and never

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: cried 'Have patience, good people!'

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: How now! back, friends! Shepherd, go off a little.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Go with him, sirrah.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Come, shepherd, let us make an honourable retreat;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: though not with bag and baggage, yet with scrip and scrippage.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Exeunt CORIN and TOUCHSTONE

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Didst thou hear these verses?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, yes, I heard them all, and more too; for some of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: them had in them more feet than the verses would bear.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: That's no matter: the feet might bear the verses.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, but the feet were lame and could not bear

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: themselves without the verse and therefore stood

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: lamely in the verse.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: should be hanged and carved upon these trees?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I was seven of the nine days out of the wonder

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: before you came; for look here what I found on a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: palm-tree. I was never so be-rhymed since

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Pythagoras' time, that I was an Irish rat, which I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: can hardly remember.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Trow you who hath done this?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Is it a man?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Change you colour?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I prithee, who?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O Lord, Lord! it is a hard matter for friends to

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: meet; but mountains may be removed with earthquakes

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: and so encounter.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, but who is it?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Is it possible?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, I prithee now with most petitionary vehemence,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: tell me who it is.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: wonderful! and yet again wonderful, and after that,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: out of all hooping!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Good my complexion! dost thou think, though I am

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: caparisoned like a man, I have a doublet and hose in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: my disposition? One inch of delay more is a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: South-sea of discovery; I prithee, tell me who is it

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: quickly, and speak apace. I would thou couldst

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: stammer, that thou mightst pour this concealed man

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: out of thy mouth, as wine comes out of a narrow-

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: mouthed bottle, either too much at once, or none at

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: all. I prithee, take the cork out of thy mouth that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: may drink thy tidings.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: So you may put a man in your belly.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Is he of God's making? What manner of man? Is his

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: head worth a hat, or his chin worth a beard?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Nay, he hath but a little beard.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, God will send more, if the man will be

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thankful: let me stay the growth of his beard, if

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thou delay me not the knowledge of his chin.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: It is young Orlando, that tripped up the wrestler's

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: heels and your heart both in an instant.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, but the devil take mocking: speak, sad brow and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: true maid.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I' faith, coz, 'tis he.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Orlando?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Orlando.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Alas the day! what shall I do with my doublet and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: hose? What did he when thou sawest him? What said

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: he? How looked he? Wherein went he? What makes

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him here? Did he ask for me? Where remains he?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: How parted he with thee? and when shalt thou see

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him again? Answer me in one word.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: You must borrow me Gargantua's mouth first: 'tis a

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: word too great for any mouth of this age's size. To

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: say ay and no to these particulars is more than to

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: answer in a catechism.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But doth he know that I am in this forest and in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: man's apparel? Looks he as freshly as he did the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: day he wrestled?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: It is as easy to count atomies as to resolve the

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: propositions of a lover; but take a taste of my

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: finding him, and relish it with good observance.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I found him under a tree, like a dropped acorn.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: It may well be called Jove's tree, when it drops

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: forth such fruit.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Give me audience, good madam.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Proceed.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: There lay he, stretched along, like a wounded knight.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: becomes the ground.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Cry 'holla' to thy tongue, I prithee; it curvets

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: unseasonably. He was furnished like a hunter.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, ominous! he comes to kill my heart.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I would sing my song without a burden: thou bringest

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: me out of tune.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do you not know I am a woman? when I think, I must

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: speak. Sweet, say on.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: You bring me out. Soft! comes he not here?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO and JAQUES

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: 'Tis he: slink by, and note him.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I thank you for your company; but, good faith, I had

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: as lief have been myself alone.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And so had I; but yet, for fashion sake, I thank you

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: too for your society.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: God be wi' you: let's meet as little as we can.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I do desire we may be better strangers.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I pray you, mar no more trees with writing

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: love-songs in their barks.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I pray you, mar no more of my verses with reading

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: them ill-favouredly.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Rosalind is your love's name?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Yes, just.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I do not like her name.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: There was no thought of pleasing you when she was

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: christened.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: What stature is she of?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Just as high as my heart.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You are full of pretty answers. Have you not been

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: acquainted with goldsmiths' wives, and conned them

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: out of rings?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Not so; but I answer you right painted cloth, from

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: whence you have studied your questions.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You have a nimble wit: I think 'twas made of

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Atalanta's heels. Will you sit down with me? and

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: we two will rail against our mistress the world and

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: all our misery.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I will chide no breather in the world but myself,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: against whom I know most faults.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The worst fault you have is to be in love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: 'Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am weary of you.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I found

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: you.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: He is drowned in the brook: look but in, and you

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: shall see him.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: There I shall see mine own figure.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I'll tarry no longer with you: farewell, good

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Signior Love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am glad of your departure: adieu, good Monsieur

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Melancholy.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exit JAQUES

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: [Aside to CELIA]  I will speak to him, like a saucy

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: lackey and under that habit play the knave with him.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do you hear, forester?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Very well: what would you?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I pray you, what is't o'clock?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: You should ask me what time o' day: there's no clock

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: in the forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then there is no true lover in the forest; else

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sighing every minute and groaning every hour would

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: detect the lazy foot of Time as well as a clock.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And why not the swift foot of Time? had not that

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: been as proper?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By no means, sir: Time travels in divers paces with

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: divers persons. I'll tell you who Time ambles

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: withal, who Time trots withal, who Time gallops

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: withal and who he stands still withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Marry, he trots hard with a young maid between the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: contract of her marriage and the day it is

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: solemnized: if the interim be but a se'nnight,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Time's pace is so hard that it seems the length of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: seven year.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who ambles Time withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: hath not the gout, for the one sleeps easily because

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: he cannot study, and the other lives merrily because

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: he feels no pain, the one lacking the burden of lean

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and wasteful learning, the other knowing no burden

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of heavy tedious penury; these Time ambles withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who doth he gallop withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With a thief to the gallows, for though he go as

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: softly as foot can fall, he thinks himself too soon there.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who stays it still withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With lawyers in the vacation, for they sleep between

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: term and term and then they perceive not how Time moves.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Where dwell you, pretty youth?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With this shepherdess, my sister; here in the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: skirts of the forest, like fringe upon a petticoat.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Are you native of this place?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Your accent is something finer than you could

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: purchase in so removed a dwelling.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I have been told so of many: but indeed an old

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: religious uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: in his youth an inland man; one that knew courtship

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: too well, for there he fell in love. I have heard

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him read many lectures against it, and I thank God

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I am not a woman, to be touched with so many

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: giddy offences as he hath generally taxed their

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: whole sex withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Can you remember any of the principal evils that he

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: laid to the charge of women?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: There were none principal; they were all like one

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: another as half-pence are, every one fault seeming

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: monstrous till his fellow fault came to match it.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I prithee, recount some of them.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, I will not cast away my physic but on those that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are sick. There is a man haunts the forest, that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: abuses our young plants with carving 'Rosalind' on

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: their barks; hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: on brambles, all, forsooth, deifying the name of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Rosalind: if I could meet that fancy-monger I would

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: give him some good counsel, for he seems to have the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: quotidian of love upon him.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am he that is so love-shaked: I pray you tell me

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: your remedy.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: There is none of my uncle's marks upon you: he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: taught me how to know a man in love; in which cage

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of rushes I am sure you are not prisoner.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What were his marks?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A lean cheek, which you have not, a blue eye and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sunken, which you have not, an unquestionable

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: spirit, which you have not, a beard neglected,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: which you have not; but I pardon you for that, for

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: simply your having in beard is a younger brother's

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: revenue: then your hose should be ungartered, your

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: bonnet unbanded, your sleeve unbuttoned, your shoe

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: untied and every thing about you demonstrating a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: careless desolation; but you are no such man; you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are rather point-device in your accoutrements as

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: loving yourself than seeming the lover of any other.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe I love.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Me believe it! you may as soon make her that you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: love believe it; which, I warrant, she is apter to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: do than to confess she does: that is one of the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: points in the which women still give the lie to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: their consciences. But, in good sooth, are you he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that hangs the verses on the trees, wherein Rosalind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: is so admired?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I swear to thee, youth, by the white hand of

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Rosalind, I am that he, that unfortunate he.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Love is merely a madness, and, I tell you, deserves

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: as well a dark house and a whip as madmen do: and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the reason why they are not so punished and cured

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: is, that the lunacy is so ordinary that the whippers

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are in love too. Yet I profess curing it by counsel.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Did you ever cure any so?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Yes, one, and in this manner. He was to imagine me

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: his love, his mistress; and I set him every day to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: woo me: at which time would I, being but a moonish

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: youth, grieve, be effeminate, changeable, longing

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and liking, proud, fantastical, apish, shallow,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: inconstant, full of tears, full of smiles, for every

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: passion something and for no passion truly any

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thing, as boys and women are for the most part

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: cattle of this colour; would now like him, now loathe

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him; then entertain him, then forswear him; now weep

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: for him, then spit at him; that I drave my suitor

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: from his mad humour of love to a living humour of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: madness; which was, to forswear the full stream of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the world, and to live in a nook merely monastic.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And thus I cured him; and this way will I take upon

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: me to wash your liver as clean as a sound sheep's

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: heart, that there shall not be one spot of love in't.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I would not be cured, youth.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I would cure you, if you would but call me Rosalind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and come every day to my cote and woo me.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Now, by the faith of my love, I will: tell me

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: where it is.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Go with me to it and I'll show it you and by the way

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you shall tell me where in the forest you live.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Will you go?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: With all my heart, good youth.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay you must call me Rosalind. Come, sister, will you go?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt
